prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not letting my parents access my phone history?
TL;DR mother wants me to put tracking app on phone I pay for, so she can 'see if I'm using time effectively'. 

I'm a college student and 700 miles away from home. Now where I live isn't a bad area per say, but every major town has it's rough spots. I have paid for my phone for the past few months after buying a little straight talk smart phone. Not a big deal right? I like having data that I can use and being able to talk to who I want. (Not forced to talk to people I don't like). When I want is a big deal to.  I don't have a car so I get on the weekend shuttle to Walmart for essentially everything. I don't leave the locked in campus. (We have walls that Trump dreams about y'all)(two lines of police intercept people coming in). She still says she wants me to download this app so she can she where I am at all times. Is this normal? I haven't lived with her for two years and she is known to be bipolar. Am I really disrespectful for not downloading an app for her to monitor my phone usage and tract my location?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking if the person in the "AITA" post is in the wrong for not letting their parents access their phone history. Let me break this down.

First, the person is a college student 700 miles away from home. They have their own phone that they pay for. The mother wants them to install a tracking app to monitor their location and phone usage, claiming it's to see if they're using their time effectively. The person is hesitant because they value their privacy and autonomy. They mention that they don't live with their parents anymore and that their mom is bipolar, which might affect her need for control.

I need to consider the context. The person is an adult, living independently, even if they're in college. Privacy is a big deal, especially for adults. The fact that they're paying for their own phone adds another layer; their parents don't have a right to access it unless there's a specific agreement. The mother's request could be seen as overstepping, especially since they're not in the same household anymore. Also, the mention of the mother's bipolar disorder might explain her behavior, but it doesn't necessarily justify invading the child's privacy.

Is the mother's concern valid? Maybe she's worried about her child's safety, but the location tracking might be excessive if the area isn't dangerous. The person also mentions that the campus is secure, so maybe the mother's worries are unfounded. The key points here are autonomy, privacy, and the adult child's right to manage their own life. 

In most cases, parents don't have the right to monitor their adult children's phones without consent. The person isn't in the wrong for setting boundaries. The mother's request is more about control than actual necessity. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
